The accusations were part of a scathing 72-page report that Minnesota\'s Department of Human Rights released last month. The report concluded the Minneapolis Police Department displayed a pattern of racial discrimination over a 10-year period. One section is about how officers allegedly used covert social media accounts to target and surveil Black organizations, for no reasons of public safety or suspected criminal activity. The Urban League, which advocates for the Black community, is named as one of those organizations. No further details are given. "I would\'ve expected and would\'ve hoped that the Minnesota Department of Human Rights would at least have provided some greater clarity about what actions were taken and by whom," said Steven Belton, president and CEO of Urban League Twin Cities. "It seems to me it\'s the height of irony, if not in fact the heart of hubris, that in a scathing report about the lack of transparency on the Minneapolis Police Department, that the [MDHR] itself is committing that same lack of transparency." Even in a private meeting, Belton says the MDHR Commissioner Rebecca Lucero wouldn\'t share any specifics about how police allegedly targeted the league online. Belton says she cited privacy laws. WCCO has also asked investigators for the supporting evidence that led to their conclusions in the report, but was denied due to privacy reasons. The law does give the commissioner some discretion to share information from case files. "I can\'t think of any investigative purpose for not sharing that information, and I can\'t think of a circumstance that would justify the use of that discretion that is more apt than the one right here," Belton said. "So it is frustrating. I would say beyond frustrating. I\'m frankly angry." Belton believes the secrecy around that one piece of the report sullies the entire thing, which is unfortunate, he says, because he\'s grateful for the MDHR putting it out. "What [the report] did, importantly, was justify what has been a community narrative for a very long period of time," Belton said. "We\'ve known of this racist policing on the part of the Minneapolis Police Department for a number of years." When the report came out, Interim Police Chief Amelia Huffman gave this statement, which read in part: "We\'re committed to providing effective, constitutional police service -- the service people across our community want and need and deserve … There is no place in the Minneapolis Police Department for bias or discrimination." The city has stopped talks with the MDHR until the online spying allegations are confirmed. First published on May 29, 2022 / 10:11 PM CDT © 2022 CBS Broadcasting Inc. All Rights Reserved. ©2024 CBS Broadcasting Inc. All Rights Reserved.'}]

joined the ABC 6 News Team in May 2022. While attending the University of Minnesota – Twin Cities, she was an active member of her sorority, Alpha Phi, as well as a staff member for a university publication called Golden Magazine. Just before her senior year she interned right here at ABC 6 News as a part-time producer and reporter. Mayzie graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Professional Journalism and minored in sports management. Education She is born and raised right here in Minnesota, and grew up in Wayzata, a suburb west of Minneapolis. After high school, Mayzie attended the University of Minnesota – Twin Cities. Personal Interests Mayzie has loved all things publication and news since she was a young girl. When she has free time, she enjoys traveling, spending time with friends and family and playing with her bulldog Matilda. She loves crime shows, concerts, being on the lake and being by the ocean. Mayzie is very excited to move to Rochester and find out what Southeastern Minnesota is all about! Have a good news story? You can email Mayzie at molson@kaaltv.com or message her on Facebook or Twitter. Any person with disabilities who needs help accessing the FCC Public file should email news@kaaltv.com or call (507) 288-7555 This website is not intended for users located within the European Economic Area. © KAAL-TV, LLC A Hubbard Broadcasting Company ABC 6 News Follow'}]

become a CTEP AmeriCorps member Learn how to host a CTEP member resources for current members Resources for instructors Group projects addressing the digital divide Rent SPNN's studio or classroom Hire us for community events, forums, nonprofit videos, or studio shows Schedule a tour for your group Whether you are a beginner, emerging, or somewhere in-between we have a documentary program for you. Our Doc U program is for first time media makers. This 16 week program takes you through the process of story construction, learning our cameras and field gear (while shooting your documentary) and Adobe Premiere (while editing your doc). You (and your fellow participants) will screen your five minute documentary at our community screening. This program runs January through April. Applications are open November 1-November 30 with interviews in December. This program is made possible through a grant from the McKnight Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts. Spotlight Shorts is a program for folks with 1-3 years of media making experience and have done short documentaries, but not necessarily longer docs. In this program we will spend time building cinematography skills, more advanced lighting, and editing with storytelling in mind. Participants will work on their own short documentary (5-20 minutes) and work on two other members documentaries. This program runs November through March. The next cohort will run July-December. Applications will be open June 1. This program is made possible with a grant from the Minnesota State Arts Board. Emerging artists who are looking to build skills in pitching, story development, funding, and marketing can do so in our New Angle Fellows program. This program runs October through May. We meet every other week. Applications are open September 1-September 30. This program is made possible with a grant from the Jerome Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts. With a grant from the Raymond J Christensen Foundation of the St. Paul & Minnesota Foundation SPNN is able to offer $15,000 post production grants to emerging artists through our Fresh Vantage Program. Applications for 2024 will open March 15. Our documentary programs are made possible with support from the following foundations."}]

'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Caitlin is a weeknight anchor/producer at KTTC. He joined KTTC in September 2023 as a weeknight anchor. Jess anchors KTTC News Today and KTTC News at Noon. Kelsey Marier is an Anchor/Producer for KTTC News Today, which airs from 4:30 - 7 a.m. She has worked for Gray Television since January 2016. Megan is the Weekend Anchor and Producer for KTTC and a Multimedia Journalist during the week. Noah joined KTTC/KXLT as a Multimedia Journalist in April 2021. Charles joined KTTC as a Weekend Morning Anchor/Multimedia Journalist in September 2023 after graduating from the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Zach joined KTTC-TV in December of 2019 and now serves as KTTC\'s Digital Anchor on KTTC News Now. Michael joined KTTC as News Director in 2022. Chuck joined KTTC in 1972. In early 2018, Stevan made the switch to be the producer for the KTTC morning show. Quinn is the Minnesota Capitol Bureau Reporter for KTTC News. Micah is a photographer for KTTC. Olivia Prondzinski joined the KTTC team as a multimedia journalist in November of 2022. Leah joined KTTC in January 2023. Kendall is a producer for KTTC News Today and News at Noon. Eric (Min San Thu) joined KTTC as a Multimedia Journalist in June 2023. Matt joined KTTC as a multimedia journalist in July 2023 after graduating from Temple University in Philadelphia PA. Mitchell Breuer joined KTTC in 2024. Karina joined KTTC in early 2024 as a producer and reporter Addie has been with KTTC since Jan. 2024. Tom joined the KTTC News in May 2000 as co-anchor of the 6pm and 10pm weekday newscasts. Jessie joined Midwest Access in April 2024. In 2024, Williams joined the Midwest Access team as a host & contributor. Missy has been with KTTC for more than 30 years. Silentia is an award-winning video producer who hails from Southern California. Nick Jansen is Chief Meteorologist at KTTC-TV in Rochester, MN. Watch Meteorologist Ted Schmidt on KTTC News Today at 5:00 and on the KTTC News at Noon. Sarah Gannon joined KTTC in June, 2017 as the Weekend Meteorologist and Reporter. David joined the KTTC team in July 2023 and comes from the great state of Ohio – Go Bucks! Derrick joined KTTC August of 2022. Nik joined KTTC in spring 2023 after starting his career in Fairbanks, Alaska. He was born and raised in Brainerd and is very excited to continue his career in his home state. Nathan joined the KTTC team as the Weekend Sports Anchor in March of 2024. Peggy Dalland joined the KTTC sales department in 2004 and was promoted to General Sales Manager in 2023. Ann Glazier is the newly created Digital Sales Manager for KTTC & KXLT. Bill Grinde joined the KTTC sales staff in 2019. Luke began his broadcast career as an account executive with FOX 47 in 2013, eventually rising to the role of Local Sales Manager in 2017. Jim Jorgenson joined the KTTC sales staff in 2002. Eric Shoars is the son of entrepreneurs, so he knows how hard our local business owners are working to keep the lights on. Ryan Enright is a previous small-business owner who joined the KTTC sales staff in 2020. Laurie joined KTTC in October of 2010 following a ten year stint in both radio sales and underwriting at Twin Cities Public Television. With Dana’s passion for people, enthusiasm and desire to help businesses grow, it was natural that sales chose her. Kelly Wessels is the Regional Account Executive for KTTC and KXLT FOX 47. Ashley Dwyer joined KTTC as a Digital Sales Coordinator. Cindy Ruchotzke joined KTTC as a Sales Assistant in June 2018. Jennifer Wilcox joined KTTC in May 2012. Danika joined KTTC/FOX 47 in 1998. Jon is an Engineer at KTTC. Nick joined the KTTC Engineer team in late summer 2022. Tony is the Director of Technology at KTTC. Tim is the Senior Director on the Production team at KTTC. Ian is a Newscast Director for KTTC. Becca has been working as a Master Control Operator/Audio Op for four years. James Skifter is a Technical Media Producer for the morning shows at KTTC. Michael Crowley is a Technical Media Producer and Morning Show Director. Andrew is a Master Control Operator/ Director at KTTC. Ben Mulholland has been with KTTC for 10 years. Larissa joined KTTC as a Creative Services Producer in October 2023. Sarah joined the KTTTC/FOX 47 Creative Services department in 2022. Lucas joined the creative Services Department in Winter 2023. Ryan rejoined the Creative Services team in 2024. Jennie Hinz joined KTTC in 2024. Stephanie Hedrick joined KTTC/KXLT as Vice-President & General Manager in January 2022. Jodi is KTTC\'s Office Manager. Brendan Ford is the Director of Broadcast Operations for Gray Television, Inc. Jon Decker is the White House Correspondent and Senior National Editor for Gray Television and has been a member of the White House Press Corps since 1995. Peter Zampa joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in June 2015 as a multimedia journalist. Brendan Cullerton joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in March 2022 as a multimedia journalist after spending four years covering state, local, and federal politics for the CBS affiliate in Milwaukee. I started working at Gray TV’s Washington D.C. bureau in May of 2023. I found my calling for news while attending Butler University during the Ferguson Riots after the killing of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager. During the chaotic times is when I realized how facts and storytelling can really impact a community. Molly Martinez rejoined Gray Television in March 2022 as a multimedia journalist in the Washington News Bureau. She previously covered politics at Gray TV\'s KFYR-TV in Bismarck, N.D. Ashonti Ford joined Gray Television in August of 2023. Ford is a well-traveled watchdog journalist who has worked for newsrooms around the nation, including; Tampa, Kansas City, Decatur, Wichita and Salisbury. Stetson Miller joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in February 2023 as a multimedia journalist after working at WTOP, WJZ in Baltimore and WCBD in Charleston, SC. Josh Rultenberg joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in July 2022 as a multimedia journalist. Annie has worked at various news outlets in Washington, D.C., including covering the 2020 and 2022 election cycles for C-SPAN. Before that she worked at local stations in Louisiana and Virginia. Joshua worked at several local stations before moving to Washington, D.C.. There he launched a national morning show, "The National Desk" for Sinclair. He now works as a producer for the Gray Washington News Bureau. Leah Vredenbregt joined the Gray Washington Bureau team in June 2023 as a weekend producer. She is a recent University of Missouri grad who worked for three years in mid-Missouri news, with internships across the country in both local and national news outlets. Michael is a born and raised Ohioian who got his photojournalism start at his alma mater Ohio University working for PBS in 2007. He has gone on to work for several media outlets both locally and nationally, shooting award winning news and documentary stories, garnering him an Emmy and Edward Murrow award. Tyler Smith joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in July 2019 as a photojournalist/editor. Sarah Meklir joined the Gray Television Washington News Bureau in September 2023 as a production assistant after working as an intern for the DC Bureau in the summer of 2023. She is currently studying journalism at the University of Maryland.'}]
